journal-meta.journal-title: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control

title-group.article-title: Observer-based finite-time exponential l2 ‚àí l‚àû control for discrete-time switched delay systems with uncertainties

contrib-group.aff: Institute of Automation, Qufu Normal University, Qufu, Shandong, People‚Äôs Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Guangdeng Zong, Institute of Automation, Qufu Normal University, Qufu 273165, Shandong, People‚Äôs Republic of China. Email: zonggdeng@yahoo.com.cn

abstract.p: The problem of observer-based finite-time exponential l2 ‚àí l‚àû control is studied in this paper for a class of discrete-time switched systems with time delay and uncertainties. The observer-based controller is designed to guarantee that the developed closed-loop system is robust finite-time exponential l2 ‚àí l‚àû stabilizable for all admissible uncertainties. By resorting to the average dwell time approach and Lyapunov‚ÄìKrasovskii functional technology, some new delay-dependent criteria guaranteeing finite-time boundedness and stabilizability with exponential l2 ‚àí l‚àû performance are developed. The observer-based finite-time exponential l2 ‚àí l‚àû controller is also designed by virtue of a cone complement linearization method. Finally, a numerical example is provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed results.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Switched systems are an important class of hybrid systems, which are composed of a family of continuous-time or discrete-time subsystems and a rule that orchestrates the switching among them (Liberzon and Morse, 1999; Lin and Antsaklis, 2009). Many real-world processes and systems can be modeled as switched systems, such as power electronics, embedded systems, chemical processes, computer-controlled systems, the automotive industry, etc. Time delays and uncertainties are the inherent features of many physical processes, which may degrade system performance, cause oscillation and lead to instability. In view of the strong engineering background and the complexity of the interaction among the continuous-time or discrete-time dynamics, discrete-event dynamics and time delay, switched systems with time delay and/or uncertainties have attracted special attention during the past decade. Considerable results have been reported in the earlier literature, see Zhang and Yu (2009), Zong et al. (2010), Wu and Zheng (2009), Sun et al. (2007), Deaecto et al. (2011), Wu et al. (2011), Zong et al. (2012), Branicky (1998), DaÔ¨Äouz et al. (2002), Wu et al. (2009), Hespanha and Morse (1999), Zhang et al. (2008), Wu et al. (2010) and the references therein.

It is worth pointing out that most of the existing research regarding stability and control is considered in the infinite-time interval. However, in many practical applications, such as manufacturing systems, chemical process, and power systems, we are more concerned about the state response over a finite-time horizon rather than the asymptotical stability. For example, in order to complete a set of experiments, a space vehicle will be guaranteed to remain in a specified orbit for a given length of time. In a chemical process, the temperature, pressure or some other parameters should be kept within a specified bounds in a prescribed time interval. Therefore, to study the transient performances of a system, Dorato (1961) introduced the concept of finite-time stability to the control literature. Then, Amota et al. generalized the definition of finite-time stability to the concept of finite-time boundedness for continuous-time systems (Amato et al., 1999) and for discrete-time systems (Amato et al., 2004a). Since then, the problems of finite-time stability and boundedness with or without time-delay have obtained extensive research. Amato and Ariola (2005) considered the finite-time stabilization of discrete-time linear systems subject to disturbances generated by an exosystem. The problem of finite-time stabilization was studied by Amato et al. (2006) for a class of continuous-time linear systems. Finite-time stabilization and finite-time boundedness problem with input constraints were studied by Ichihara and Katayama (2009) for linear discrete-time time-invariant systems. Now, for various linear systems, the concepts of finite-time stability and boundedness have been further generalized. The concept of finite-time stability was induced by Feng et al. (2005) for a class of linear singular system with time-varying parametric uncertainties and exogenous disturbances, and finite-time control problem was considered. Liu and Sun (2008) explored a new concept of finite-time stability for linear time-invariant impulsive systems, to name but a few. However, very few results about finite-time stability and finite-time boundedness for switched systems are discussed. Considering the wide application of switched systems in practice, some scholars have paid more attention to the study of the finite-time problem for switched systems. For example, finite-time stability and stabilization problems were researched by Du et al. (2010) for continuous-time switched linear system. The problems of finite-time boundedness and finite-time weighted L2-gain were studied by Lin et al. (2011) for a class of continuous-time switched delay systems with time-varying exogenous disturbances. At present, the study of finite-time stability and finite-time boundedness as well as finite-time control for switched system is still in the initial stage.

In real physical systems, the existence of disturbances may lead to poor performance. Therefore, how to reduce the effect of the disturbances becomes an important issue. In fact, the problem of finite-time boundedness has taken the effect of disturbances into account, and the system output is bounded but does not converge to zero. However, we expect that the output can be as close to zero as possible in finite-time interval. Here, we further consider the finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû control such that the output has a better performance. The exponential l2‚àíl‚àû control problem is applicable when there exists external noise whose energy is assumed to be bounded. Its objective is to find a stable controller such that the closed-loop system is exponentially stable, and the system gain from l2 to l‚àû space is below a prescribed level. Up to date, to the best of the authors‚Äô knowledge, the problem of finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû control for discrete-time switched systems have not been fully investigated.

Moreover, the states of system are not usually measurable in many real-world systems due to the technical or economic constraints. Under these circumstances, the observer-based state feedback controller is introduced to solve this problem. In recent years, observer-based control problem for switched systems has been studied extensively. Li et al. (2011b) studied the problem of tracking control based on observer for switched linear systems with time-varying delay. The observer-based reliable exponential stabilization was presented by Li et al. (2011a) for switched systems with faulty actuators by virtual of an average dwell time approach. For a class of discrete-time switched nonlinear systems with time delay, the nonfragile observer was designed to analyze the stability in Xiang et al. (2011). However, all of the above-mentioned results are about the Lyapunov stability. For the finite-time problem with observer-based control scheme, there are few reports in the current literature. This has motivated us to study the observer-based finite-time control problem for a discrete-time switched delay system combined with exponential l2‚àíl‚àû performance.

In this paper, the problem of observer-based finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû control is considered for a class of discrete-time switched systems with time delay and uncertainties. By resorting to the average dwell time approach and Lyapunov‚ÄìKrasovskii functional technology, some new delay-dependent criteria guaranteeing finite-time boundedness and stabilizability with exponential l2‚àíl‚àû performance are developed. The observer-based finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû controller is also designed by virtue of a cone complement linearization (CCL) method. Finally, a numerical example is provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed results.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: The notation used in this paper is fairly standard. For real symmetric matrices X and Y, the notation X‚â•Y (respectively, X>Y) means that the matrix X‚àíY is positive semi-definite (respectively, positive definite); AT represents the transpose of matrix A; Œªmax(¬∑) (respectively, Œªmin(¬∑)) is the maximum (respectively, minimum) eigenvalue of (¬∑). Let ‚Ñù denote the set of real numbers; ‚Ñùn stands for the n-dimensional Euclidean space; ‚Ñùn√óm is the set of all n√óm real matrices. Let ‚Ñ§‚â•0 denote the set of nonnegative integers, ‚Ñ§+ represent the set {1,2,‚Ä¶}, and N={1,2,‚Ä¶,ŒΩ} means a set of positive numbers. The notation diag(¬∑) is a diagonal matrix. In symmetric block matrices, we use an asterisk (*) to represent a term that is induced by symmetry. Here ‚à•¬∑‚à• is used to denote the vector Euclidean norm, and I refers to an identity matrix with appropriate dimensions. Matrices, if their dimensions are not explicitly stated, are assumed to have compatible dimensions for algebraic operations.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p: Consider the following discrete-time switched system with time-delay

where x(k)‚àà‚Ñùn is the state, u(k)‚àà‚Ñùm is the controlled input, y(k)‚àà‚Ñùp is the measured output, z(k)‚àà‚Ñùq is the controlled output, œâ(k)‚àà‚Ñùl is the disturbance input belonging to l2[0,‚àû) and satisfies

Here œï1(s) is the initial value function, and œÉ(k):‚Ñ§‚â•0‚ÜíN={1,2,‚Ä¶,œÖ} is the switching signal specifying which subsystem activates at a certain time instant. For each i‚ààN, Ai‚àà‚Ñùn√ón,Adi‚àà‚Ñùn√ón,B1,i‚àà‚Ñùn√ól,B2,i‚àà‚Ñùn√óm,Ci‚àà‚Ñùp√ón,Cdi‚àà‚Ñùp√ón,Ei‚àà‚Ñùq√ón,Edi‚àà‚Ñùq√ón,Gi‚àà‚Ñùq√óm are constant matrices of appropriate dimensions. Here ŒîAi(k), ŒîAdi(k), ŒîB2,i(k) are time-varying but norm bounded uncertainties which satisfy

where Mi, Ni, Ndi and Nui are known matrices with appropriate dimensions, which present how the uncertain parameters Fi(k) influence the nominal matrices of system (Œ£œÉ). The Fi(k) are unknown time-varying matrices satisfying

Remark 1. It is almost impossible to get an exact mathematical model for a dynamical system due to the complexity of the system, environmental noises and uncertain delays. Hence, the time delay and uncertainties are considered in system (Œ£œÉ). The structure of uncertain parameters in (5) and (6) has been widely studied in the issues of robust control and filtering for uncertain systems; see, e.g., Xu et al. (2001a) and Shi et al. (1999). It comprises the ‚Äòmatching conditions‚Äô, and many physical systems can be either exactly modeled in this manner or overbounded by (6).
In this paper, switching sequence is defined as
The imth subsystem is activated for any k‚àà[km,km+1), and it is assumed that the states of system (1) do not jump at the switching instants.
For system (Œ£œÉ), we construct the following observer-based state feedback controller

where x^(k)‚àà‚Ñùn and y^(k)‚àà‚Ñùp are the estimated state and estimated output, œï2(s) is the initial function of estimated state; for each i‚ààN, Ki‚àà‚Ñùm√ón,Kdi‚àà‚Ñùm√ón, and Li‚àà‚Ñùn√óp are state feedback gains and observer gain, respectively, which will be determined later. Define the state estimate error e(k)=x(k)‚àíx^(k), then the resulting closed-loop error system is as follows
where
Now we give the following definition, which is an extension of that in Amato et al. (2004b) to discrete-time switched systems with time delay.
Definition 1. (Finite-time stability) Given three positive constants c1,c2,N with c2>c1 and N‚àà‚Ñ§+, a positive-definite matrix R>0, and a switching signal œÉ(k)‚ààùí©, system
is said to be finite-time stable with respect to (c1,c2,N,R,œÉ) if

Remark 2. Lyapunov asymptotic stability and finite-time stability are independent concepts: a system which is finite-time stable may not be Lyapunov asymptotic stable; conversely a Lyapunov asymptotic stable system could not be finite-time stable if, during the transients, its state exceeds the prescribed bounds (Amato et al., 2004b, 2006; Liu and Sun, 2008).

Given both some initial conditions and an external disturbance working on the systems, the general idea of finite-time boundedness presents the boundedness of the state of these systems over a finite-time interval (Amato et al., 1999). In the following, we extend this definition to the one for the discrete-time switched systems with time delay.

Definition 2. (Robust finite-time boundedness) Given four positive constants c1,c2,N, Œ¥ with c2>c1 and N‚àà‚Ñ§+, a positive-definite matrix R>0, and a switching signal œÉ(k)‚ààN, under conditions (4)‚Äì(6), system (10) is said to be robust finite-time bounded with respect to (c1, c2, N, R, Œ¥, œÉ) via an observer-based state feedback controller in the form of (Œ£œÉ1) if condition (13) holds.

Remark 3. It is obvious that finite-time stability is implied by finite-time boundedness. So, in the following, we only study the finite-time boundedness of a discrete-time switched delay system with uncertainties. As pointed out by Du et al. (2010) and Lin et al. (2011), both finite-time stability and finite-time boundedness are different from the concept of a reachable set. Reachable set means a set of states that a system attains under some given bounded inputs and starting from some given initial conditions, which is usually considered in an infinite-time interval.

Definition 3. (Robust finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû stabilization) Given four positive constants c1,c2,N, Œ¥ with c2>c1 and N‚àà‚Ñ§+, a positive-definite matrix R>0, and a switching signal œÉ(k)‚ààN, system (Œ£œÉ) is said to be robust finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû stabilizable with respect to (c1, c2, N, R, Œ¥, œÉ) if there exists an observer-based state feedback controller in the form of (Œ£œÉ1) such that the following conditions are satisfied:

list-item.p: the closed-loop system (10) is robust finite-time bounded under conditions (4)‚Äì(6);
under the zero-initial condition, the exponential l2‚àíl‚àû performance

sec.p: is guaranteed for all nonzero œâ(k) satisfying (4), where Œ≥>0 is a prescribed scalar, and
In this case, the controller (Œ£œÉ1) is said to be observer-based finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû controller, and Œ≥ is a finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû performance index.
Now, we revisit the definition of average dwell time as follows.

Definition 4 (Average dwell time Zhang and Yu, 2009). For any k‚â•k0 and any switching signal œÉ(œÇ),k0‚â§œÇ<k, let NœÉ denote the switching numbers of œÉ(œÇ) during the interval [k0,k]. If there exist N0‚â•0 and œÑa>0 such that NœÉ(k0,k)‚â§N0+(k‚àík0)/œÑa, then œÑa and N0 are called average dwell time and the chatter bound, respectively.

Remark 4. The average dwell time approach has been shown to be an effective tool for choosing certain switching laws, under which the asymptotical or exponential stability can be obtained (Hespanha and Morse, 1999; Zhang et al., 2008; Zhang and Yu, 2009). Without loss of generality, in this paper, we assume N0=0 for simplicity as commonly used in the literature (Zhang and Yu, 2009).
Lemma 1 (Xu et al., 2001b). Let D,E and F be matrices with appropriate dimensions. Suppose that FTF‚â§I, then for any scalar Œµ>0, the following holds:

sec.title: Main results
sec.p: In this section, the main results are presented. First, we consider the problem of finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû control for the nominal system (by setting FœÉ(k)(k)=0). Under these circumstances, system (Œ£œÉc) becomes the following system

sec.title: Finite-time boundedness
sec.p: In this section, the following theorem shows the finite-time boundedness of system (15).

Theorem 1. For the given scalars r>1, Œº‚â•1, d>0, system (15) is finite-time bounded with respect to (c1, c2, N, R, Œ¥, œÉ) via an observer-based controller, if there exist positive scalars Œª1, Œª2, Œª3, positive-definite matrices Pi>0, Qi>0, i‚ààùí© such that the following inequalities hold

Remark 5. In the proof of Theorem 1, the Lyapunov‚ÄìKrasovskii function contains the term

where r>1. Generally speaking, in order to obtain the exponential stability of discrete-time switched systems with time delay, the term (36) is also used in Lyapunov‚ÄìKrasovskii function, in which the parameter satisfies 0<r<1 (Ma et al., 2011; Wang et al., 2012). Here, r>1 is a prerequisite to guarantee system finite-time boundedness.
When œâ(k)=0, the finite-time stability of system (15) can be obtained from Theorem 1.

Corollary 1. For the given scalars r>1, Œº‚â•1, d>0, system (15) (œâ(k)=0) is finite-time stable with respect to (c1, c2, N, R, œÉ) via an observer-based controller, if there exist positive scalars Œª1, Œª2, Œª3, positive-definite matrices Pi>0, Qi>0, i‚ààùí© such that (17), (20) and the following inequalities hold

sec.title: Finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû performance analysis
sec.p: From Theorem 1, we obtain the following result of the finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû performance index.

Theorem 2. For the given scalars r>1, Œº‚â•1, d>0, Œ≥>0, system (Œ£nœÉc) is finite-time bounded with respect to (c1, c2, N, R, d, œÉ) via an observer-based controller under the exponential l2‚àíl‚àû performance index Œ≥, if there exist positive scalars Œª1, Œª2, Œª3, positive-definite matrices Pi>0, Qi>0, i‚ààùí© such that (17), (18), (19), (20), (21) and the following inequality hold

Proof. From Theorem 1, we know that system (15) is finite-time bounded. In the following, we prove that the finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû disturbance attenuation performance of system (Œ£nœÉc) is guaranteed for all nonzero œâ(k)‚ààl2[0,‚àû) under the zero initial condition.
Based on (29), under the zero initial condition, there holds
Hence,
When œÉ(k)=i, we have
Taking this together with (40), one obtains
which implies that the performance index (14) can be guaranteed. This completes the proof of Theorem 2. ‚ñ°

Remark 6. Finite-time boundedness guarantees that the state and output are both bounded in finite-time interval under the existence of disturbances. The exponential l2‚àíl‚àû performance index is further used to reduce the effect of the disturbances, which leads to that the output has a better performance.

sec.title: Observer-based finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû controller design
sec.p: Now, we are in a position to present a solution to the problem of observer-based finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû controller design for system (Œ£œÉ) with Fi(k)=0.

Theorem 3. For the given scalars r>1, Œº‚â•1, d>0, Œ≥>0, system (Œ£œÉ)(Fi(k)=0) is said to be finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû stabilizable with respect to (c1, c2, N, R, Œ¥, œÉ), where c2>c1, R=[R1R2*R3]>0, œÉ‚ààùí©, under the observer-based state feedback controller in the form of (Œ£œÉ1), if there exist positive scalars Œª1, Œª2, Œª3, positive-definite matrices Pi=diag{P1i,P3i}>0, Xi=diag{X1i,X3i}>0, Qi=[Q1iQ2i*Q3i]>0, Ki, Kdi, Li, i‚ààùí© such that (19), (21) and the following inequalities hold
where Œº~=r1‚àíNŒº‚àíNœÑa.
Proof. Using Schur complement formula, the inequalities (18) and (40) are equivalent to the following two inequalities, respectively,
Let

then X1i=P1i‚àí1,X3i=P3i‚àí1. Substituting Pi,Xi,Qi, A~i,A~di,B~1,i,B~2,i,E~i,E~di into (17), (50), (51) and (20), respectively, then (45), (46), (47) and (48) can be obtained, respectively. This completes the proof of Theorem 3.

Remark 7. Note that the conditions in Theorem 3 are no longer linear matrix inequalities due to (49). In what follows, a CCL method will be used to convert the original problem into the nonlinear minimization problem:

According to the cone complementarity problem of He et al. (2008), if the solution of the above minimization problem is 4nœÖ, we can say from Theorem 3 that system (Œ£œÉ) is finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû stabilizable with respect to (c1, c2, N, R, Œ¥, œÉ) via an observer-based finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû controller (Œ£œÉ1). The algorithm in detail is as follows.
Step 1. Choose a sufficient initial Œ≥ini>0 such that (19), (21), (45), (46), (47), (48) and (52) are feasible. Set Œ≥s0=Œ≥ini.
Step 2. Find a feasible set (P1i0,P3i0,X1i0,X2i0,Q1i0,Q2i0,Q3i0,Ki0,Kdi0,Li0) satisfying (19), (21), (45), (46), (47), (48) and (52). Set k=0.
Step 3. Solve the following minimization problem:
Set P1ik+1=P1i,X1ik+1=X1i,P3ik+1=P3i,X3ik+1=X3i.
Step 4. If the matrix inequalities (19), (21), (45), (46), (47), (48) and (52) are satisfied, and

holds for some sufficient small scalar œµ>0, then decrease Œ≥ini to some extent and set Œ≥s0=Œ≥ini and go to Step 2. If one of the conditions in (49) and (53) is not satisfied within a specified number of iterations, then exit. Otherwise, set k=k+1 and go to Step 3.

Remark 8. In the process of solving the controller, the terms Pi and Pi‚àí1 often occur simultaneously, which leads to the conditions are nonlinear. In order to get the controller gains, the nonlinear matrix inequality must be transformed into a linear matrix inequality. In fact, the term Pi‚àí1 can be replaced by ‚àí2I+Pi based on (Pi‚àí1‚àíI)Pi(Pi‚àí1‚àíI)‚â•0. However, from Zong et al. (2009), we can know that the cone complement linearization method is better at obtaining less conservative results than the above inequality. Hence, in our paper, we employ the CCL method to transform the nonconvex feasibility problem to some sequential optimization problem, although it is more difficult and complex than other inequality techniques.

sec.title: Observer-based finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû controller design with uncertainties
sec.p: In the following, we directly present the result for observer-based finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû controller design with uncertainties.

Theorem 4. For the given scalars r>1, Œº‚â•1, d>0, Œ≥>0, system (Œ£œÉ) is robust finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû stabilizable with respect to (c1, c2, N, R, Œ¥, œÉ), where c2>c1, R=[R1R2*R3]>0, œÉ‚ààùí©, under the observer-based state feedback controller in the form of (Œ£œÉ1), if there exist positive scalars Œª1, Œª2, Œª3, Œµi, positive-definite matrices P1i>0, P3i>0, Q1i>0, Q2i, Q3i>0, X1i>0,X3i>0, Ki, Kdi, Li, i‚ààùí© such that (19), (21), (45), (47), (48), (49) and the following inequalities hold
where
Proof. According to the Schur complement formula, Equation (54) is equivalent to the following inequality
By Lemma 1, we have
which guarantees that system (Œ£œÉ) is robust finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû stabilizable. This complements the proof of Theorem 4.
Remark 9. The nonlinear conditions also can be transformed to the nonlinear minimization problem by virtual to the cone CCL method:

sec.title: Numerical examples
sec.p: Now, we provide an example to show the effectiveness of the main results in this paper.
Example 1. Consider system (Œ£œÉ) with the following parameters when œÖ=2:

Let c1=1,c2=20,R1=R3=I,R2=0,Œº=1.1. Solving Theorem 4, we can obtain Tables 1 and 2 which demonstrate the relations between the parameters Œ≥min and r for d=2,N=10, and the relations between dmax and r under N=10, Œ≥=0.1, respectively.

caption.p: Values of Œ≥min and r when d=2,N=10.
Values of dmax and r when N=10,Œ≥=0.1.

sec.p: From Table 1, we can see that r<1.29 under the parameters c1=1,c2=20,Œº=1.1,d=2,N=10. Moreover, Œ≥min is related to the parameter r, and a smaller Œ≥min allows a larger r for the given c1,c2,Œº,d and N.
By Table 2, it can be seen that a larger value of parameter r leads to a smaller œÑmax, and the feasible maximum value of r is r‚â§1.29 for the given c1, c2,Œº,Œ≥ and N.

Choosing N=14, r=1.15, Œ≥=0.5, c1=1,c2=20,Œº=1.1,d=3,œÑa=2 and solving Theorem 4, we can obtain œÑa>œÑa*=ceil[0.4647]=1, which shows that condition (21) is satisfied. Therefore, for any switching signal œÉ(t)‚ààùí© with average dwell time œÑa‚â•1, system (Œ£œÉ) is robust finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû stabilizable with respect to (1, 20, 13, I, 0.5, œÉ) under the observer-based state feedback controller in the form of (Œ£œÉ1). Moreover, the state feedback controller gains Ki, Kdi and the observer gain Li,i=1,2 are given as follows:
Suppose that the switching sequence is 212121‚ãØ, which is shown in Figure 1.

Choose the initial value function œï1(s)=[0.2‚àí0.2]T and the disturbance œâ(k)=0.5sin(k)k+1. Figure 2 shows the trajectory of disturbance œâ(k), from which we can see that the disturbance decays but is bounded in finite-time interval [014].

caption.p: The trajectory of the disturbance œâ(k).

sec.p: Figure 3 presents the state phase plot of system (Œ£œÉ), from which we can see that the system state stays within a certain bound over a finite-time horizon by the designed observer-based state feedback controller.

caption.p: The state phase plot of the system (Œ£œÉ).

sec.p: Figure 4 depicts the trajectory of the system output z(k) under two cases: finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû control and finite-time control. The former is that the system is finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû stabilizable via observer-based state feedback controller, and the latter is that the system is finite-time stabilizable via observer-based state feedback controller. From Figure 4, we can see that, under these two cases, the outputs are both bounded. However, the output has a better performance with the finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû control, which further illustrates the effectiveness of the exponential l2‚àíl‚àû performance. Above all, system (Œ£œÉ) is finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû stabilizable with respect to (1, 20, 14, I, 0.5, œÉ) via the designed observer-based state feedback controller (Œ£œÉ1) with the controller gains and observer gain in (58).

caption.p: The trajectory of system z(k) with (solid) and without (dash) performance Œ≥.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, we have investigated the problem of observer-based finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû control for a class of discrete-time switched systems with time delay and uncertainties. The observer-based controller has been designed to guarantee that the developed closed-loop system is finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû stabilizable for all admissible uncertainties. Some new delay-dependent criteria guaranteeing finite-time boundedness and stabilizability with exponential l2‚àíl‚àû performance have been developed by resorting to the average dwell time approach and Lyapunov‚ÄìKrasovskii functional technique. The observer-based finite-time exponential l2‚àíl‚àû controller has also been obtained by virtue of CCL method. Finally, we have provided a numerical example to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed results.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This work was supported by National Natural Science Foundation (NNSF) of China (grant numbers 60904022, 60974127, and 61104136), Natural Science Foundation of Shandong Province (grant numbers ZR2011FM033 and ZR2010FQ002), and Shandong Provincial Scientific Research Reward Foundation for Excellent Young and Middle-aged Scientists of China (grant number BS2010DX011).
